title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
üéØ Learning Objective
Derive individual demand curves from utility maximization theory
Our Example: Two goods - üç∫ Rum (x-axis) - ‚öîÔ∏è Swords (y-axis)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
üéØ Learning Objective
Derive individual demand curves from utility maximization theory
Our Example: Two goods - üç∫ Rum (x-axis) - ‚öîÔ∏è Swords (y-axis)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
The Budget Constraint

Basic Setup
Consumer income: \(M\) to spend on two goods: - Rum (\(R\)) with price \(p_R\) - Swords (\(S\)) with price \(p_S\)


Budget Constraint Equation
\[p_R \cdot R + p_S \cdot S = M\]


Slope-Intercept Form
\[S = \frac{M}{p_S} - \frac{p_R}{p_S} \cdot R\]
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Initial Scenario

Our Assumptions

Income: \(M = \$120\)
Price of Rum: \(p_R = \$4\) per bottle

Price of Swords: \(p_S = \$6\) per sword



Initial Budget Constraint
\[4R + 6S = 120\]


Slope-Intercept Form
\[S = 20 - \frac{2}{3}R\]
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Utility Function

Cobb-Douglas Utility Function
\[U(R,S) = R^{0.6} \cdot S^{0.4}\]
Why Cobb-Douglas? - Mathematically tractable - Realistic diminishing marginal utility - Widely used in economics
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Utility Maximization

The Key Condition
Marginal Rate of Substitution = Price Ratio
\[MRS_{R,S} = \frac{MU_R}{MU_S} = \frac{p_R}{p_S}\]


For Cobb-Douglas Function

\(MU_R = 0.6 \cdot R^{-0.4} \cdot S^{0.4}\)
\(MU_S = 0.4 \cdot R^{0.6} \cdot S^{-0.6}\)



Therefore:
\[MRS_{R,S} = 1.5 \cdot \frac{S}{R}\]
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Finding the Optimal Bundle

Setting MRS = Price Ratio
\[1.5 \cdot \frac{S}{R} = \frac{4}{6} = \frac{2}{3}\]


Solving for S in terms of R
\[S = \frac{4}{9}R\]


Substituting into Budget Constraint
\[4R + 6 \cdot \frac{4}{9}R = 120\]


Result: \((R^*, S^*) = (18, 8)\)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Price Changes: Rum = $3

New Price Ratio
\[1.5 \cdot \frac{S}{R} = \frac{3}{6} = \frac{1}{2}\]


New Relationship
\[S = \frac{1}{3}R\]


New Budget Constraint
\[3R + 6S = 120\]


New Optimum: \((R^*, S^*) = (24, 8)\)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Price Changes: Rum = $6

New Price Ratio
\[1.5 \cdot \frac{S}{R} = \frac{6}{6} = 1\]


New Relationship
\[S = \frac{2}{3}R\]


New Optimum: \((R^*, S^*) = (12, 8)\)
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Price Changes: Rum = $2

Following the same process‚Ä¶


New Optimum: \((R^*, S^*) = (36, 8)\)
Notice: Swords consumption stays constant at 8!
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:

crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Mathematical Demand Function

General Cobb-Douglas Result
For \(a = 0.6, b = 0.4, M = 120, p_S = 6\):


Rum Demand Function:
\[R^*(p_R) = \frac{72}{p_R}\]


Swords Demand Function:
\[S^* = 8\]
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Key Economic Insights

üìä Elasticity Analysis
For demand function \(R = \frac{72}{p_R}\):
\[\varepsilon_{R,p_R} = -1\]
Unit Elastic Demand at all points!


üí° Income and Substitution Effects
When price decreases from $4 to $3: - Total Effect: \(\Delta R = 24 - 18 = 6\) bottles - Both effects reinforce the law of demand
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:

Market analysis

title: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords
text:
Key Takeaways

‚úÖ What We Learned

Budget constraints limit consumer choices
Utility maximization determines optimal bundles

Price changes create predictable demand responses
Mathematical functions can be derived analytically
Elasticity provides insights into behavior



üéØ The Framework
Essential tools for economic analysis and policy evaluation
crumbs: Deriving Demand for Rum and Swords

text:

Explore interactive simulations

title: Gross Domestic Product
text:
Measuring the Economy
How do we measure how well a country is doing? If you are an economist, you do this by measuring the output of an economy. We use the measure, ‚ÄúGross Domestic Product‚Äù. Sounds totally gross dude :) but what it really means is the take all the finished goods and services produced within a country within a year and adding it up. We call this GDP or Gross Domestic Product. It is one way of measuring how well and economy is doing.




 Back to top

title: Human vs AI Score Analysis with Section Comparison
text:
This analysis compares performance scores between Human and AI participants in a test with scores ranging from 0 to 15. The analysis includes both overall comparisons and section-specific comparisons (MW vs TTH sections).

title: Human vs AI Score Analysis with Section Comparison
text:
Statistical Analysis

Overall Statistical Comparison


=== OVERALL COMPARISON ===
Two-sample t-test results:
t-statistic: -1.82 
p-value: 0.0732 
95% Confidence Interval for difference in means: -3.36 to 0.15 
Cohen's d (effect size): 0.426 




Section-Specific Statistical Analysis


=== SECTION-SPECIFIC COMPARISONS ===



--- Section: MW ---
Sample sizes: AI = 24 , Human = 18 
t-statistic: -2.157 
p-value: 0.0372 
95% CI for difference: -4.2 to -0.13 
Cohen's d (effect size): 0.633 

--- Section: TTH ---
Sample sizes: AI = 15 , Human = 13 
t-statistic: -0.549 
p-value: 0.5874 
95% CI for difference: -4.13 to 2.39 
Cohen's d (effect size): 0.206
crumbs: Human vs AI Score Analysis with Section Comparison

title: Human vs AI Score Analysis with Section Comparison
text:
Key Findings

Overall Performance


OVERALL RESULTS:
‚Ä¢ Human participants achieved an average score of 9.62 out of 15
‚Ä¢ AI participants achieved an average score of 8.01 out of 15
‚Ä¢ Difference: Humans scored 1.61 points higher on average ( 20.1 % difference)
‚Ä¢ The difference is not statistically significant (p = 0.0732 )
‚Ä¢ Effect size (Cohen's d) = 0.426 , indicating a small to medium effect




Section-Specific Performance



SECTION-SPECIFIC RESULTS:

--- Section MW ---
‚Ä¢ Human average: 10.39 , AI average: 8.23 
‚Ä¢ Difference: 2.16 points
‚Ä¢ Statistically significant difference (p = 0.0372 )
‚Ä¢ Effect size: 0.633  ( medium to large )

--- Section TTH ---
‚Ä¢ Human average: 8.54 , AI average: 7.67 
‚Ä¢ Difference: 0.87 points
‚Ä¢ No statistically significant difference (p = 0.5874 )
‚Ä¢ Effect size: 0.206  ( small to medium )
crumbs: Human vs AI Score Analysis with Section Comparison

title: Human vs AI Score Analysis with Section Comparison
text:
Conclusion
The analysis reveals both overall and section-specific performance differences between human and AI participants in this assessment. The faceted analysis allows us to understand whether performance differences are consistent across sections or vary by section type. Key insights include:

Overall Performance: The combined analysis provides a general comparison between human and AI performance across all data.
Section-Specific Patterns: The faceted analysis reveals whether certain sections favor one group over another, which could indicate section-specific strengths or weaknesses.
Statistical Significance: Both overall and section-specific statistical tests help determine whether observed differences are likely due to chance or represent genuine performance differences.
Effect Sizes: Cohen‚Äôs d values provide insight into the practical significance of any differences, helping to understand not just whether differences exist, but how meaningful they are.

This comprehensive analysis framework allows for both broad and detailed insights into Human vs AI performance patterns across different test sections.
crumbs: Human vs AI Score Analysis with Section Comparison
